s.text: But in 1993, pro-choicers won passage of a federal law protecting clinics from obstruction, on the reasoning that they're legal medical facilities.
In the 1990s, pro-lifers have used fetal diagrams to illustrate the horror of "partial birth" abortions.
Roe struck down abortion laws in part on the grounds that they interfered with doctors' professional judgment.
Today, feminism remains a bad word, but Republicans have adjusted their philosophy of motherhood to accommodate women's political power (hence their attention to "soccer moms").
Today, feminism remains a bad word, but Republicans have adjusted their philosophy of motherhood to accommodate women's political power (hence their attention to "soccer moms").
Recognizing this trap, the National Right to Life Committee refuses to talk about birth control.

This debate began with birth control in the late 1960s (George Bush earned the nickname "Rubbers" for sponsoring family planning legislation) and continued through abortion in the 1970s to AIDS in the 1980s.
Pro-lifers had the better of this argument in the late 1960s and 1970s, because pro-choicers got mixed up with the sexual revolution and the anti-war movement.
Murderer vs. murder: Half of all Americans say that killing a fetus is murder, but few regard the woman who participates in the killing as a murderer.
The longer abortion remains legal, the more people read about casual abortions, the more they forget how gory and repugnant abortion was when it was illegal.
The longer abortion remains legal, the more people read about casual abortions, the more they forget how gory and repugnant abortion was when it was illegal.
For example, we may agree with pro-lifers that abortion is wrong while agreeing with pro-choicers that people are entitled to make their own reproductive decisions.

In the 1980s, this combination proved doubly vulnerable to the New Right's critique: Women's careers bore the bloodstains of abortions.

Over the years, pro-choicers have continued to invoke medical expertise, particularly by rigging polls to ask whether "a woman and her doctor" (as opposed to a woman alone) should be entrusted with the abortion decision.
